title: Ep. 3 What is Life: Inside and Outside: a Deep Dive into Entropy, Its History and Deeper Meaning
description:
Glen joins me for Episode 3 of our conversations about the nature of the origin of life. He wants to approach this topic from the standpoint of a specific shared set of definitions of terms, so we begin by recapping Episode 2 definitions of complexity, chaos, order, and entropy, and then take a deep dive into the history of the concept of entropy and its importance.

To understand thermodynamic systems, you. have to look at the differences between the inside and the outside.
Kolmogorov complexity measure
The inside can be very complex, but once you cross the boundary to the outside, the complexity is greatly reduced in terms of how you interact with it.
Example:  a watch is highly complex on the inside, but you interact with it through the hands and that is much less complex. Once the boundary is crossed the complexity transforms.

Chaos can be looked at in various ways - from an archetypal context to an emotional state to the strict definition it has within physics.

When something is disordered, there is still a reference point you can go back to, but in chaos, there is no reference point.

The matrix of predictability and determinism.
Deterministic but not predictable - this describes chaotic systems
Unpredictable and non-deterministic - a true random number generator
Predictable but non-deterministic - a computer running a program
  (there's some intelligence out there that we are responding to)

Information - Julian Barbour article, Bit from It.
  In the Shannon sense - how many bits
  In the sense of telling you something useful (i.e. tall or short, which
    can encompass a lot of different states. Yes/No questions
    don't necessarily map to number of states.
In the sense of black holes, holographic principle.
In the sense of semantic information

Chaos - strange attractors are acting in phase space.
  Order coming. out of chaotic systems (unpredictable, but they are
  bounded)
  Shapes in multiple dimensions. Your brain is not made to see the world
  the way Mother Nature sees it.

Entropy - most definitions are incomplete. Ex: a measure of disorder, a measure of number of states - statistical mechanics (Boltzmann)

but 20 years before that.
Late 1700's - steam engine, heat going in, mechanical work coming out.
Joule discovered that meat and mechanical work were the same thing.
  1st law of thermodynamics - Conservation of Energy
Carnot - early 1800's - maximum efficiency, hot minus cold divided by heat
Lord Kelvin - concentrated on the heat stroke
Clausius - had to include the return stroke, the compression, to view it 
  as a cycle. In the return, the waste heat gets dumped.
The entropy gets transferred at the moment you begin cleaning up the bedroom.
Heat transfer divided by temperature
Entropia - to transform - a transformation current makes sure the energy doesn't get into trouble (like a big brother)
Change or flow in energy divided by the temperature

Entropy is a bookkeeping device to make sure that you don't violate Carnot's principle.
How much free energy depends on the difference between hot and cold.
Entropy is the mileage indicator for the disorganization, not the disorganization itself.
Carnot - The max efficiency is T hot minus T cold divided by T h
Kelvin - perfect engine
Clausius - perfect refrigerator

Entropy is. qualitative metaphysical statement. You can't go backwards.
The big question is does the arrow of time only move forwards because of entropy? Or does the second law occur (does entropy always increase) because the arrow of time already has a direction?

People assume science is a step by step process - but you stare at it for a long time, and then one day, the answer comes.

Qualitative boundary between the inside and the outside.
Inside: thermodynamic entropy ( states/probabilities/energies)
  tends to maximum disorder, only works at thermal equilibrium
  Probability of going. back is vanishingly small.
Outside:  Out of equilibrium will tend towards a new equilibrium and tend towards maximum forgetfulness. You can't go back because you have no idea whereto came from. (self-organized criticality & complexity economics.

Any living system will degrade over time. Can't reproduce a living system from an adult because errors have already crept in over time.
To keep renewing and restoring, you need an original copy (DNA)
  a roadmap, a copy of the original state (DNA, sexual reproduction - combining two different copies acts as an error correction mode)

Entropy increases always when you are trying to do work - a less then perfect conversion.
A transformation of entropy from one side to the other side goes up.

When omplexity on the inside is hidden, you're dealing with a simple object (emergence.
Weak emergence -boundary is artificial - cylinders, pistons, etc.
Strong emergence - system is making its own boundary (self-organizing,  maintaining its own boundary.

Playlist for the whole 6 part series:  https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLoARw9zo4EUZhxqfaqYU5yjy0-Tr8RlB4
